abstract_summ: The model predictions emphasize the importance of major public health interventions in controlling COVID-19 epidemics.We use reported case data up to 31 January 2020 from the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention and the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission to parameterize the model.The official data for the time evolution of active cases of COVID-19 pandemics around the world are available online.Abstract This study aimed to present a simple model to follow the evolution of the COVID-19 (CV-19) pandemic in different countries.However, the results presented here revealed that this approach can be used as an alternative for the exponential growth model, traditionally employed as a prediction model, and serve as a valuable tool for investigating how protective measures are changing the evolution of the pandemic.
title_summ: Predicting COVID-19 peaks around the worldA Recursive Bifurcation Model for Predicting the Peak of COVID-19 Virus Spread in United States and GermanyA surprising formula for the spread of Covid-19 under aggressive managementA model to predict COVID-19 epidemics with applications to South Korea, Italy, and SpainCan we predict the occurrence of COVID-19 cases?Considerations using a simple model of growthUnderstanding Unreported Cases in the COVID-19 Epidemic Outbreak in Wuhan, China, and the Importance of Major Public Health Interventions
title_abstract_phrases: Predicting COVID-19 peaks around the worldThe official data for the time evolution of active cases of COVID-19 pandemics around the world are available online.We use reported case data up to 31 January 2020 from the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention and the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission to parameterize the model.Understanding Unreported Cases in the COVID-19 Epidemic Outbreak in Wuhan, China, and the Importance of Major Public Health InterventionsWe develop a mathematical model to provide epidemic predictions for the COVID-19 epidemic in Wuhan, China.A model to predict COVID-19 epidemics with applications to South Korea, Italy, and SpainIn this work, our team develops a differential equations model of COVID-19 epidemics.The model predictions emphasize the importance of major public health interventions in controlling COVID-19 epidemics.
